title: Trump stands by Waltz as the president and his allies deploy a familiar playbook | CNN Politics
content:
Follow: 
            President Donald Trump not only stood by his embattled national security adviser on Tuesday, amid fever-pitch conversations about Mike Waltzâ€™s fate in the wake of an extraordinary security breach; he invited him for a seat at the table in the Cabinet Room to send an undeniable message of support.
     
            â€œNo, I donâ€™t think he should apologize,â€ Trump said, after branding it â€œthe only glitchâ€ of his new administration. â€œI think heâ€™s doing his best.â€
     
            The president insisted classified information had not been shared in a group chat with his national security team about military strikes in Yemen. He declined to answer how he reached that conclusion, but the fact that he addressed the matter and took repeated questions underscored how his advisers said they believed that only he could defuse the crisis.
     
            After watching an explosive Senate hearing in the morning, the White House sought to contain the fallout by using the presidentâ€™s bully pulpit to try and change the subject. Trump appeared on camera, surrounded by his ambassador picks, for a previously unscheduled meeting where he also signed executive actions on conservative pet issues like requiring proof of citizenship for voter registration and declassifying the FBIâ€™s Russia probe documents.
     
            His afternoon remarks served a dual purpose of sending a message to allies on Capitol Hill and beyond in hopes of quelling a deepening controversy over how it came to be that war planning was debated and discussed in a group chat on Signal. The presidentâ€™s loyalists employed a familiar page from the Trumpian playbook of attacking the messenger â€“ the media â€“ as they dealt with one of the biggest challenges of the young presidency.
     
            As top White House officials began to carry out that strategy, people close to Trump â€“ some of whom had been wary of Waltzâ€™s survival rate on Monday after it first emerged he had added an Atlantic editor to the chat â€“ argued that if the national security adviser could stay above the fray for another day or so the story would die down and he would remain.
     
            â€œI take full responsibility,â€ Waltz told Fox in an interview that aired later Tuesday night. â€œI built the group. My job is to make sure everythingâ€™s coordinated,â€ he added, while disparaging The Atlanticâ€™s editor-in-chief Jeffrey Goldberg and not explaining how his number was in his phone.
     
            A day earlier, it was Waltz who was one of the first people to discuss the story with the president, two sources familiar with the talks told CNN.
     
            During their conversation, Waltz told the president that he had never met or spoken with The Atlanticâ€™s editor-in-chief Jeffrey Goldberg, against whom the president has long held a deep, personal grudge, according to one of the sources.
     
            By the time Trump was fully briefed on the matter from Waltz and others Monday â€“ a task one person familiar with the matter described as unpleasant â€“ heâ€™d already been questioned by reporters in the Roosevelt Room about the embarrassing episode. He claimed ignorance.
     
            But the first hints of what was to come had started that morning when top officials had begun receiving word from the White House shortly after 9 a.m. that the encrypted chat where theyâ€™d been freely discussing plans to strike Houthi targets in Yemen had inadvertently included an editor from The Atlantic, according to people familiar with the conversations.
     
            Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth was in the air, having departed for a trip to Asia, only hours before the story emerged. By the time he stepped off his airplane in Hawaii, he was visibly irate, denying an allegation he dropped detailed war plans into the chat.
     
            In Washington, Director of National Intelligence Tulsi Gabbard and CIA Director John Ratcliffe were forced to adjust in real-time their preparations for a high-profile congressional hearing on worldwide threats a day later, anticipating tough new lines of questioning on the administrationâ€™s handling of classified information.
     
            And inside the White House, the top aides who had been included in the group text were left to piece together exactly what had happened â€“ and how to tell Trump, who had never before heard of the Signal app his aides were using to discuss his military plans.
     
            The president expressed some frustration with the story and its fallout behind closed doors, sources said, but by Tuesday morning, Trump downplayed the episode as â€œthe only glitchâ€ of his administration so far, both diminishing the severity of what happened while also tacitly acknowledging he viewed the matter as an unforced error.
     
            It was also evident he was ready to move on, shrugging off the incident as a commonplace technical snafu rather than a serious breach of the governmentâ€™s most closely held secrets.
     
            â€œSometimes people are hooked in, and you donâ€™t know theyâ€™re hooked in,â€ he said later Tuesday in the Cabinet Room.
     
            For a president long intent on rooting out leakers in his midst â€“ and whose own handling of classified documents resulted in a criminal investigation â€“ the Signal chat episode amounted to a major test of his new administration.
     
            Internal administration dynamics were laid bare in the chats, including differences of opinion between some members of the national security team and Vice President JD Vance, who suggested in one message Trump may not be â€œaware how inconsistent this is with his message on Europe right now,â€ according to The Atlantic.
     
            And questions of competence swirled in Washington around some of Trumpâ€™s unorthodox selections for top national security positions, including Hegseth and Gabbard, who were left to defend themselves after many of Trumpâ€™s rivals had already called into question their fitness for their roles.
     
            â€œYou have to learn from every experience,â€ Trump said Tuesday, suggesting the entire incident was just another day at the office.
     
            But even as the president and his advisers worked feverishly to downplay the entire matter and diminish the specific war planning details that were shared on the Signal messaging app, top Democrats in Congress were calling for the resignations of Waltz and Hegseth.
     
            Some Republicans also voiced their frustration.
     
            â€œThis has got to be the last time something this big and dumb happens,â€ Sen. Kevin Cramer said, adding someone needed to â€œapologize and say itâ€™ll never happen again.â€
     
            â€œItâ€™s such a major first strike, in my mind. I donâ€™t know how many strikes you get. This oneâ€™s a really big first one. Maybe itâ€™s worth two,â€ the North Dakota Republican said.
     
            Indeed, whether there would be any consequences for the officials involved in the chat was a matter of intense speculation among aides, some of whom still vividly remember the tumultuous string of firings from Trumpâ€™s first time in office.
     
            Multiple Trump administration officials told CNN on Monday they were shocked by the matter, with at least two speculating that this could result in the dismissal of one of their colleagues.
     
            By Monday afternoon, however, the White House press secretary put out word that Trump retained confidence in Waltz.
     
            And when the president brought together his ambassador nominees Tuesday afternoon, he gave a full-throated defense of his national security adviser.
     
            â€œI think it was very unfair the way they attacked Michael,â€ Trump said.
     
            Trump personally likes Waltz and has been pleased with the job heâ€™s done so far, officials said, which is part of why he quickly chose to stand by him despite the embarrassing story, people familiar with the strategy told CNN.
     
            But another leading reason, those people said, is that admitting wrongdoing, or going so far as to fire Waltz over the digression, would feed into the criticism of his administration.
     
            Instead, Trumpâ€™s team, in part fueled by the president himself, adopted the well-worn playbook of downplaying the seriousness of the situation, denying the most egregious parts of the story and disparaging the journalist behind it.
     
            Still, even many Trump allies acknowledged privately that the incident reflected poorly on the administrationâ€™s general competence. As soon as the story published, it was blasted out in multiple text threads throughout the administration, with officials reacting with disbelief, according to those who spoke to CNN privately.
     
            When officials first briefed Trump on the matter on Monday, he expressed his disdain for Goldberg, sources said.
     
            The president has long disliked the longtime Washington reporter, dating back to his 2020 story in which Goldberg reported that Trump described Americans who died in war as â€œlosersâ€ and â€œsuckers.â€
     
            â€œYou couldnâ€™t have picked a worse person than Goldberg to add to the chat,â€ one person close to Trump said.
     
            But as the White House scrambled to contain fallout from the incident, senior administration officials were also reviewing the use of Signal amid concerns there is an overreliance on the encrypted app.
     
            Signal was widely used during the first Trump administration, multiple former administration officials told CNN, including at times to plan and coordinate sensitive meetings. Trump officials, both during the presidentâ€™s first term and his current term â€“ as well as the transition period in between the election and January 2025 â€“ have also used signal to communicate with reporters.
     
            â€œEveryone is on Signal, all day and night,â€ one official told CNN, speaking on condition of anonymity to discuss internal deliberations in the West Wing. â€œThat may well change.â€
     
            However, none of the officials said they could ever recall an instance where classified information relating to a military attack was ever discussed in such a manner, though some suggested officials may have used Signal to leak classified information to reporters.
     
            â€œWe all used signal to communicate at a staff level,â€ one of the former administration officials, who worked for a Cabinet-level official, said. â€œBut the planning and execution of sensitive operations would have been ran by the President/NSC members from the Situation Room, regardless of whether it took place during â€˜normalâ€™ working hours. That would include the decision making and information sharing process leading up to the operation, in the form of a meeting or secure VTC,â€ this person said, referring to video conferencing.
     
            A sense of concern was palpable inside the West Wing and across key agencies as questions emerged over whether new guidance or rules should be put in place for internal communications.
     
            White House chief of staff Susie Wiles, who was on the group chat reported by the Atlantic, was among the senior officials who apparently did not raise questions or concerns that a highly sensitive conversation was taking place on the commercial messaging app. Officials declined to answer questions about whether the text chat violated legal procedures for the handling of such information.
     
            Trump, speaking Tuesday, suggested use of the app may be a thing of the past, at least for his top officials.
     
            â€œI donâ€™t think itâ€™s something weâ€™re looking forward to using again,â€ he said.

title: New York Giants to sign free agent quarterback Russell Wilson
content:
Follow: 
            The New York Giants are signing a Super Bowl-winning free agent quarterback to the roster. And despite rumors, itâ€™s not Aaron Rodgers.
     
            The G-Men signed Russell Wilson, the team announced on Wednesday.
     Let's do it, @DangeRussWilson ğŸ˜¤ pic.twitter.com/xBZxuoLW5Z 
            The deal was first reported Tuesday by ESPNâ€™s Adam Schefter, who says that Wilson will sign a one-year contract worth up to $21 million with $10.5 million guaranteed.
     
            Wilson confirmed the news, posting a photograph of MetLife Stadium to X, tagging the Giants with the caption, â€œBeen here beforeâ€¦ canâ€™t wait to do it again.â€
     
Related article
NFL free agency kicks off with a flurry of big moves
 
            The 36-year-old Wilson will be entering his 14th NFL season this fall.
     
            Wilson played the first 10 seasons of his career with the Seattle Seahawks, where he was instrumental in leading the Seahawks to their only championship at Super Bowl XLVIII in 2014.
     
            The 10-time Pro-Bowler joined the Denver Broncos prior to the 2022 season, but he couldnâ€™t find the success in the Mile High City that he enjoyed in Seattle. With Wilson under center, the Broncos missed the postseason in 2022 and 2023.
     
            After the 2023 season, Wilson signed with the Pittsburgh Steelers. He began the season with an injured calf, but took over the starting role in October and led the team to victory in six of his first seven games at quarterback.
     
            The Steelers stumbled down the stretch however, losing four consecutive games to finish the regular season. Pittsburgh still managed to make the playoffs, but were knocked out in the Wild Card round by the rival Baltimore Ravens.
     Been here beforeâ€¦ canâ€™t wait to do it again. #MetLife @Giants pic.twitter.com/6BevBmOLKW 
            The Giants have struggled to find consistency from the quarterback position since the retirement of Eli Manning following the 2019 season, and the Giants have only made two playoff appearances since 2011.
     
            Wilsonâ€™s signing comes after the Giants inked a deal with quarterback Jameis Winston last week, who started seven games for the Cleveland Browns last season.

title: Momodou Taal: Visa of Cornell University student fighting deportation is revoked by the State Department
content:
Follow: 
            Attorneys for a Cornell graduate student whose student visa was recently revoked and has been targeted for deportation by the Trump administration said the case will be a test to determine whether the US government can target people for expressing views that are critical of the government.
     
            Attorneys for Momodou Taal, a doctoral student at Cornell University â€“ who filed a lawsuit against the Trump administration last week â€“ spoke outside federal court in Syracuse, New York, following a hearing in the case Tuesday.
     
            Taal is accusing the Trump administration of targeting him for his participation in pro-Palestinian protests amid the Israel-Hamas war. He was told to surrender to Immigration and Customs Enforcement, according to a court filing made shortly after he asked a judge to preemptively order the government not to deport him.
     
            The student had previously faced the possibility of losing his visa â€“ after he was suspended twice by Cornell last year for alleged disruptive protest activities, and was told that his academic suspension could cause his visa to be revoked, forcing him to leave the United States.
     
            Taal has also faced criticism for comments made online immediately after the Hamas October 7, 2023, attack on Israel, killing more than 1,200 people. Taal tweeted â€œcolonised peoples have the right to resist by any means necessaryâ€ and â€œGlory to the resistance!â€
     
            He brushed off complaints about his statements in a November 2023 interview with CNN and said he was tired of constantly being asked to condemn Hamas.
     
            â€œI think itâ€™s quite racist, Islamophobic that before Iâ€™m allowed to have a view on genocide, I have to condemn a terrorist organization,â€ Taal said.
     
            â€œI can say clearly categorically I abhor the killing of all civilians no matter where they are and who does it,â€ he added.
     
            On Tuesday Taalâ€™s attorney, Eric Lee, said of the federal case, â€œit doesnâ€™t end with Momodou Taal, it starts with him, next it will be you.â€
     
            Taal did not attend the hearing, but two other plaintiffs from the lawsuit were present. Mukoma Wa Ngugi, an associate professor of literatures in English at Cornell, and Sriram Parasurama, a doctoral student, have both joined the suit.
     
            â€œMomodou, my fellow plaintiff, could not be here to deliver his statement,â€ Ngugi said. â€œIs this the country we want to live in, where a plaintiff cannot attend his own legal proceedings? It is clear that the Trump administration has no respect for rule of law or due process.â€
     
            Taalâ€™s legal action seeks an injunction to block the enforcement of two Trump executive orders which have served as the basis for the administrationâ€™s targeting of student protesters in recent weeks. The judge has not yet issued a decision on the motions, but Taalâ€™s attorneys said they are confident the law is on their side.
     
            â€œI wasnâ€™t convinced by the governmentâ€™s arguments in there,â€ Lee said. â€œBut I wasnâ€™t convinced by their arguments before either.â€
     
            CNN has reached out to the US Attorneyâ€™s Office in the Northern District of New York.
     
            Unlike other students who have received deportation orders or been targeted by immigration enforcement agents, Taal, who is a dual citizen of the United Kingdom and The Gambia, sought to preempt enforcement action by filing the lawsuit against the Trump administration.
     
            Court documents filed by Department of Justice attorneys show the State Department revoked Taalâ€™s student visa, citing his participation in the protests, which they say created a hostile environment for students on campus. The documents show the visa was revoked on March 14. 
 
            In papers filed with the court, attorneys for the Department of Justice said the visa was revoked a day before Taal filed his lawsuit, countering Taalâ€™s claims that the immigration action was done in retaliation for his lawsuit.
     
            â€œState relied upon the underlying information and assessment provided by ICE that Taal had been involved with disruptive protests and had engaged in an escalating pattern of behavior, disregarding university policies and creating a hostile environment for Jewish students,â€ the lawyers wrote.
     
            Attorneys for the Department of Justice are contesting Taalâ€™s alleged timeline of the facts, after his lawyers said undercover immigration officers showed up at his residence last week in retaliation for filing the lawsuit.
     
            Taal is one of the activists flagged for suggested deportation by Betar US, a self-described Zionist advocacy group and the only Jewish organization classified as an extremist group by the Anti-Defamation League.
     
            CNNâ€™s Andy Rose and Michelle Watson contributed to this report.

title: World Athletics plans pre-clearance testing of female category track and field athletes
content:
World Athletics plans to introduce biological pre-clearance tests for track and field athletes before they can compete in the female category, the sportâ€™s governing body announced Tuesday.
     
            These tests will screen athletesâ€™ genetic samples to determine whether they contain the SRY gene, or â€œa genetic surrogate for a Y chromosome,â€ according to the organization.
     
            The decision comes following a World Athletics Council meeting where the council agreed to adopt multiple recommended conditions of â€œeligibility in the female category.â€
     
            World Athletics president Sebastian Coe said the tests will be â€œnon-invasiveâ€ during a Tuesday press conference.

            â€œCheek swab or dry blood tests,â€ Coe said. â€œItâ€™s along the lines of something that will be administered once in the career of an athlete, a female athlete.â€
     
            Coe said the organization is still looking for a provider to carry out the tests.
     
            â€œWe will doggedly protect the female category, and weâ€™ll do whatever is necessary to do it, and weâ€™re not just talking about it,â€ Coe told reporters.
     
            â€œPreserving the integrity of competition in the female category is a fundamental principle of the sport of athletics,â€ World Athletics said in a Tuesday press release.
     
            The organization added, â€œThe majority of stakeholders consulted last month on the proposed new eligibility conditions for the female category agreed that allowing only biological female athletes to compete in the female category was essential to maintaining fairness.â€
     
            Coe reiterated this standpoint during the press conference.
     
            â€œThis we feel is a really important way of providing confidence and maintaining that absolute focus on the integrity of competition.â€
     
Related article

            Transgender athletesâ€™ participation in womenâ€™s sport has been a topical subject of late.
     
            President Donald Trump took executive action in February to deliver on a political issue central to his 2024 campaign: banning transgender women from competing in womenâ€™s sports.
     
            Trump signed an executive order titled â€œKeeping Men Out of Womenâ€™s Sportsâ€ surrounded by dozens of women and some young girls in athletic uniforms.
     
            â€œWith this executive order, the war on womenâ€™s sports is over,â€ the president said.
     
            The order is two-pronged, leaning on compliance with Title IX, which prohibits discrimination on the basis of sex in education programs or activities that receive funding from the federal government, as well as federal engagement with the private sector.
